YESTERDAY'S WEATHER.
Temperature and Barometer.
THE NEW QUARANTINE.

While the new quarantine which
went into effect yesterday is, of
course, regrettable in that it restricts
travel between Cuba and southern
ports of the United States, we do not
believe its effect will be far reaching
or that it will injure this city or island
commercially in any considerable de-
gree. People in the States are too
well aware of the sanitary work the
American government has carried on
for practically ten years on this island
to believe that any large epidemic of
yellow fever could again break out
here, and persons having any knowl-
edge whatever of the disease know
that it is almost as impossible to pre-
vent an occasional case of this trop-
ical fever here as it is to prevent
smallpox, diphtheria or any other
contagious disease in New York.

There does not seem to be in the
present instance the slightest occa-
sion for alarm. The quarantine is a
precautionary measure to which the
southern states are entitled, and we
are given the assurance that it will
be raised at the earliest possible
moment.

While the quarantine is regrettable,
the development of a case of yellow
fever in Havana is still more so, and
it appears that the responsibility
should fall in the first place on the
sanitary corps having in charge that
particular section of the city where
the disease was discovered. Pre-
ventive measures have undoubtedly
been lax there, the Dos Perlas, where
the fever victim was lodged, having
been found reeking with filth. This
would lead to the opinion that the
sanitary corps was superficial in its
inspection there, and it is reasonable
to suppose that it has been equally
lax in other places. The recent dis-
coveries at Holguin showed that the
local corps had been rather indiffer-
ent to its duties and at least one case
of yellow fever had been reported
as Bright's disease.

The whole cause of the trouble does
not lie, as might be supposed, in the
inefficiency of the head of the depart-
ment, for there is no harder worker or
more faithful officer in Cuba than
Major Jefferson Kean, supervisor of
the sanitary department.

The fault lies in the fact that he
has never had proper assistance in
sufficient numbers to bring his depart-
ment to that point of efficacy for island.
which he has worked with inexperi-
enced and apparently indifferent sub-
ordinates. When Colonel Gorgas un-
dertook to rid Cuba of yellow fever
during the first intervention he had
scores of trained army officers and the
entire American army at his com-
mand to enforce his sanitary orders
--officers who had dealt with similar
situations before and were experts in
sanitary methods. The task then was
made comparatively easy.

This is in striking contrast to the
duties that Major Kean is called upon
to perform with but three trained field
assistants--Major Fauntleroy, Captain
Allen and Captain Thomason, with
whose services no fault is to be
found. Hundreds of other employes of
the department throughout the island
are Cubans, who, however excellent
they may be, are not experienced sani-
tary workers and do not appreciate
the value of rigid, thorough, complete
work in this regard.

This is not intended to reflect on
the very capable Cuban physicians,
Dr. Lee Gutierrez, Dr. Guiteras, Dr.
Finlay and others, who have rendered
the most satisfactory and faithful ser-
vices in the diagnosing of the disease,
but their province ends here and the
sanitary corps is left to carry on the
work.

If evidence of the inability of the
Cubans--and this is not said in a
spirit of maliciousness--to cope with
the sanitary situation is needed, the
record of Cuba up to the year 1898
should be sufficient. Not until Amer-
ican sanitary officers came here in
great numbers and systematically be-
gan a campaign against disease was
this island ever completely rid at any
one time of the scourge.

If the intervention government had
expended some of the money that was
paid to inexperienced Cubans in this
department in the employ of sanitary
experts to aid the very worthy head
of this service, it is safe to presume
that both the Holguin and Havana
cases would have been avoided. True,
the administration came down here to
pour oil only on troubled political
waters, but as long as American super-
visors were appointed for each depart-
ment, it is regretable that enough oil
was not brought along to quiet all the
turbulent waters and permit a good
job to be done--especially in view of
the fact that blame will fall, whether
justly or not, on the heads of these
departments for the shortcomings of
the men under them.
